questiontext.text:
For \(F (x, y) = {@aa@}x + y^{@bb@}\), find

  1. \(\displaystyle \int_C F(x,y)\ \mathrm{d}x,\)
  2. \(\displaystyle \int_C F(x,y)\ \mathrm{d}y,\)
  3. \(\displaystyle \int_C F(x,y)\ \mathrm{d}s\)
where \(C\) is the line \(y = 2x\) from \((0, 0)\) to \((1, 2)\).

  1. \(\displaystyle \int_C F(x,y)\ dx =\)[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]
  2. \(\displaystyle \int_C F(x,y)\ dy =\)[[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]][[feedback:prt2]]
  3. \(\displaystyle \int_C F(x,y)\ ds =\)[[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]][[feedback:prt3]]

generalfeedback.text:
We know that \(F (x, y) = {@aa@}x + y^{@bb@}\), and that \(C\) is the line \(y = 2x\) from \((0, 0)\) to \((1, 2)\). We aim to evaluate the line integrals: (a) \(\displaystyle \int_C F(x,y)\ \mathrm{d}x,\) (b) \(\displaystyle \int_C F(x,y)\ \mathrm{d}y,\) and (c)\(\displaystyle \int_C F(x,y)\ \mathrm{d}s\).

(a) We solve by rewriting the integral in terms of \(x\). As we have \(x\) between \(0\) to \(1\) for the defined line segment \(C\), these are the bounds of out integral. We can then substitute \(y=2x\) to get: \[\begin{aligned} \int_C F(x,y)\ \mathrm{d}x &= \int^1_0 {@aa*x@} + (2x)^{@bb@}\ \mathrm{d}x \\ &= \left[{@aa/2*x^2@} + {@(2^bb / (bb+1))*x^(bb+1)@}\right]^1_0 \\ &= \left({@subst(1, x, exp1), simp=false@} + {@ev((2^bb / (bb+1)), simp)@}(1)^{@ev(bb+1, simp)@}\right) - \left({@subst(0, x, exp1), simp=false@} + [[define simp="true"/]] {@ev(2^bb / (bb+1), simp)@}(0)^{@ev(bb+1,simp)@}\right)\\ &= {@aa/2+2^bb / (bb+1)@} \end{aligned}\]

(b) We solve by rewriting the integral in terms of \(y\). As we have \(y\) between \(0\) to \(2\) for the defined line segment \(C\), these are the bounds of out integral. We can then substitute \(x=\dfrac{y}{2}\) to get: \[\begin{aligned} \int_C F(x,y)\ dy &= \int_0^2{@aa/2@}y + y^{@bb@}\ \mathrm{d}y \\ &=\left[{@exp2@} + \frac{y^{@bb+1@}}{{@bb+1@}}\right]^2_0 \\ &= \left({@subst(2, y, exp3), simp=false@}[[define simp="true"/]] + \frac{(2)^{@bb+1@}}{{@bb+1@}}\right) - \left({@subst(0, y, exp3), simp=false@}[[define simp="true"/]] + \frac{(0)^{@bb+1@}}{{@bb+1@}}\right) \\ &= {@aa + 2^(bb+1)/(bb+1)@} \end{aligned}\]

(c) We solve by rewriting the integral in terms of \(x\). As we have \(x\) between \(0\) to \(1\) for the defined line segment \(C\), these are the bounds of out integral. We can rewrites \(\mathrm{d}s\) as follows: \[\begin{aligned} \mathrm{d}s &= \sqrt{1+\left(\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}\right)^2}\mathrm{d}x \\ &= \sqrt{1+(2)^2}\mathrm{d}x\\ &= \sqrt{5}\mathrm{d}x \end{aligned}\] We can then substitute \(y=2x\) into the line integral to get to get: \[\begin{aligned} \int_C F(x,y)\ \mathrm{d}s &= \int^1_0 \left({@aa*x@} + (2x)^{@bb@}\right)\sqrt{5}\ \mathrm{d}x\\ &\mbox{by (a) }\\ &= {@(aa/2+2^bb / (bb+1))*sqrt(5)@} \end{aligned}\]
